revision.text:
{{Infobox professional wrestler |name = The Fabulous Moolah |birthname = Mary Lillian Ellisor{{cite web|title=1930 census listing for family of Henry and Mary Ellisor|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:SPCL-YBW}} |image = The Fabulous Moolah circa date photograph.jpg |alt = |caption = |names = Fabulous Moolah{{Cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/fabulousmoolah|title=Fabulous Moolah bio|publisher=[[WWE]]|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}
The Fabulous MoolahShields, Brian. ''Main Event: WWE in the Raging 80s'', p. 86.
Slave Girl Moolah
The Spider Lady |height = {{height|ft=5|in=6}} |weight = 138-160 lbs |birth_date = {{Birth date|1923|7|22|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Kershaw County, South Carolina]], United States |death_date = {{Death date and age|2007|11|2|1923|7|22}} |death_place = [[Columbia, South Carolina]], United States |spouse = Walter Carroll (divorced)
{{marriage|Buddy Lee|1961|1970|reason=div}} |children = 1 |billed = Columbia, South Carolina |trainer = [[Mildred Burke]]
[[Mae Young]]{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FCO/is_3_2/ai_65858906 |title=Life Begins At 77: Mae Young Interview |author=Scherer, Dave |publisher=Wrestling Digest |accessdate=April 1, 2008 |date=October 2000 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209200427/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FCO/is_3_2/ai_65858906 |archivedate=December 9, 2007 |df= }}
Johnny Long |debut = 1949 |retired = 2004 }} '''Mary Lillian Ellison''' (July 22, 1923 – November 2, 2007) was an American [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]], better known by her [[ring name]] '''The Fabulous Moolah'''. She began her career working with promoter [[Billy Wolfe]] and his wife, wrestler and trainer [[Mildred Burke]], as well as working alongside professional wrestler [[Buddy Rogers (wrestler)|"Nature Boy" Buddy Rogers]]. She won the [[NWA World Women's Championship]] in 1956 and was the most prominent holder of the title for 28 years. In the 1980s, she joined the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF, later WWE) as part of the [[1980s professional wrestling boom#Rock 'n' Wrestling Connection|Rock 'n' Wrestling Connection]] storyline, feuding with [[Cyndi Lauper]] and [[Wendi Richter]], the latter of whom defeated her for the [[WWE Women's Championship (1956–2010)|WWF Women's Championship]] In the 1990s, she returned to the WWF in a comedic role with longtime friend [[Mae Young]]. Ellison became the first woman to be inducted into the [[WWE Hall of Fame]], when she was inducted with the [[WWE Hall of Fame (1995)|class of 1995]] and became the oldest champion in the history of professional wrestling when she won the WWF Women's Championship at age 76, in 1999. In 2010, WWE recognized her as the 43rd best wrestler ever.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1289602337 |title=Full list of WWE's "Top 50 Superstars of All Time" |accessdate=January 6, 2011 |publisher=WrestleView |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101116084010/http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1289602337 |archivedate=November 16, 2010 |df= }} == Early life == Mary Lillian Ellison was born in 1923 in [[Kershaw County, South Carolina]],{{cite web|last=Kittle |first=Robert |title=Women's World Champion Wrestler "Fabulous Moolah" Dies in Columbia |url=http://www.wspa.com/midatlantic/spa/news.apx.-content-articles-SPA-2007-11-05-0014.html |work=WSPA Channel 7 website |date=November 5, 2007 |accessdate=November 5, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090317003649/http://www.wspa.com/midatlantic/spa/news.apx.-content-articles-SPA-2007-11-05-0014.html |archivedate=March 17, 2009 }} and grew up in Tookiedoo, 12 miles from [[Columbia, South Carolina|Columbia]].{{cite web|last=Higgins|first=Lee|title=Friends wrestle with loss of Fabulous Moolah|url=http://www.thestate.com/local/story/219934.html|work=[[The State (newspaper)|The State]]|date=November 4, 2007|accessdate=November 5, 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071104174801/http://www.thestate.com/local/story/219934.html |archivedate = November 4, 2007|deadurl=yes}}Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', p. 26. The youngest of five children, Ellison was the only daughter of a part Cherokee father and an [[Irish people|Irish]] mother. Her parents owned a farm, a grocery store, and a service station. When her mother died of cancer, eight-year-old Ellison went to live with her paternal grandmother and worked on her cousin's cotton farm to make money. At age 10, Ellison was still deeply distraught over her mother's death; to cheer her up, her father took her to the local wrestling matches. Ellison liked the matches, but it was not until she saw Women's Champion [[Mildred Burke]] wrestle that "they began to mean much more" to her.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 30–32. Ellison returned to the Columbia home of her father and brothers.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 36–38. She graduated [[Columbia High School (Columbia, South Carolina)|Columbia High School]],{{cite web|title=Ms Mary Lillian Ellison|url=http://dunbar.createatribute.com/registryMain.php?i_memorialid=1194215708| work=Dunbar Funeral Home|date=November 2, 2007|accessdate=November 5, 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071107025908/http://dunbar.createatribute.com/registryMain.php?i_memorialid=1194215708 |archivedate = November 7, 2007|deadurl=yes}} but at age 14 married 21-year-old Walter Carroll. They soon became parents to a daughter.{{cite web|url=http://www.mikemooneyham.com/pages/viewfull.cfm?ObjectID=BA253264-7A38-4098-A3B2F0ABE84A3973|title=Moolah Simply Fabulous|last=Mooneyham|first=Mike|accessdate=December 17, 2007|year=1995|publisher=The Wrestling Gospel|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071206015507/http://www.mikemooneyham.com/pages/viewfull.cfm?ObjectID=BA253264-7A38-4098-A3B2F0ABE84A3973 |archivedate = December 6, 2007|deadurl=yes}} A few months after the birth of her daughter, she divorced Carroll. Still only 15, she left her daughter with a friend and set out on a wrestling career of her own.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 43–45. == Professional wrestling career == ===National Wrestling Alliance=== ==== Early career (1949–1955) ==== Ellison began her wrestling career with [[Mildred Burke]]'s husband [[Billy Wolfe]], the dominant women's promoter of the time. She competed with many other female wrestlers, stepping into the ring with the likes of [[Mae Young]], [[Cecilia Blevins]] and [[Mildred Burke]]. Wolfe was notorious for advising his wrestlers to enter into sexual relationships with either himself or competing promoters to ensure additional bookings, a practice with which Ellison refused to go along.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', p. 46. She, however, soon began a romance with wrestler Johnny Long. Long later introduced Ellison to [[Jack Pfefer]] who gave her the moniker "Slave Girl Moolah".Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 60–65. By the early 1950s, Moolah was a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#V|valet]] for "Nature Boy" [[Buddy Rogers (wrestler)|Buddy Rogers]], accompanying him to the ring while providing eye candy for the male audiences and assisting Rogers against his opponents. Ellison broke up the partnership because Rogers kept pushing her to begin a sexual relationship. She then served as the valet for the Elephant Boy (Tony Olivas). Olivas was Mexican, but had very dark skin, which caused controversy when Ellison, a white woman, would kiss him on the cheek during their ring entrance routine.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 68–69. At one show in [[Oklahoma City]], a man, who thought that Olivas was a black man, attempted to stab Ellison with a knife for kissing him. Moolah later left Pfeffer's promotion and began wrestling under Boston promoters Tony Santos and [[Paul Bowser]].Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 90–91. In 1955, she began working for [[Vince McMahon, Sr.]]'s [[WWE#Capitol Wrestling Corporation (1952–63)|Capitol Wrestling Corporation]]. ==== World Champion (1956–1983) ==== On September 18, 1956, Moolah defeated [[Judy Grable]] in a 13-woman [[Battle royal (professional wrestling)|battle royal]] to win the vacant World Women's Championship, which shares a lineage with the [[NWA World Women's Championship]].Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 98–100. She was not immediately recognized by everyone as the NWA Champion because Billy Wolfe, with whom she had conflict earlier in her career, still controlled the promotion.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 104–107. After the match, Vince McMahon, Sr. dubbed Ellison with a new ring name – The Fabulous Moolah. Subsequently, June Byers came out of retirement to challenge Moolah to a match for the title. During the match, Moolah acted as the aggressor and pinned Byers to retain the championship. Moolah's first World Championship reign lasted over ten years.{{cite web|url=http://www.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingGuestColumn/oct5_schramm.html|title=Moolah:Twenty-eight years was the reign|author=Schramm, Chris|date=October 5, 1998|accessdate=January 22, 2009|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling}} Moolah successfully defended the belt against the top female wrestlers in the world, such as Judy Grable and [[Donna Christanello]], while also purporting to befriend some of the biggest celebrities of the day.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', p. 73. Moolah claimed in her book, ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', that she formed friendships with [[Elvis Presley]] and [[Jerry Lee Lewis]]. After June Byers retired in 1964, Moolah was subsequently recognized as official NWA Champion, thus making her the undisputed Women's World Champion.{{cite video|people=The Fabulous Moolah|title=Lipstick & Dynamite – The First Ladies of Wrestling|medium=DVD|publisher=[[WWE]]|date=2004}} Nevertheless, Moolah [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#D|dropped]] the belt on September 17, 1967 to [[Bette Boucher]], although she regained the title just weeks later.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestlingmuseum.com/pages/bios/halloffame/moolahbio.html|title=Hall of Fame: Fabulous Moolah|author=Slagle, Steve|work=The Ring Chronicle|accessdate=March 25, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526141104/http://www.wrestlingmuseum.com/pages/bios/halloffame/moolahbio.html|archivedate=May 26, 2011}} She also traded the belt with [[Yukiko Tomoe]] during a tour of Japan in 1968. On July 1, 1972, Moolah became the first woman allowed to wrestle at [[Madison Square Garden]], which had previously banned women's wrestling. In fact, Moolah helped overturn the ban on women's wrestling in the entire state of New York, which the [[New York State Athletic Commission]] lifted in June 1972.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 134–137. During her quest to overturn the ban, she flipped football player [[Rosey Grier|Roosevelt "Rosey" Grier]] onto his back on ''[[The Mike Douglas Show]]''. Moolah continued an uninterrupted eight-year reign before losing to [[Sue Green]] at Madison Square Garden in 1976. Moolah regained her title a short time later. She also bought the legal rights to the championship in the late 1970s, and after losing the championship for two days to Evelyn Stevens in 1978, began another long reign, defending her title for another six years. Also in the 1970s, Moolah held the [[NWA Women's World Tag Team Championship]] twice with [[Toni Rose]]. ===World Wrestling Federation/Entertainment=== ==== Rock 'n' Wrestling Connection (1983–1987) ==== {{See also|Rock 'n' Wrestling Connection}} In 1983, [[Vince McMahon|Vince McMahon, Jr.]] began expanding the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF) nationally, and Moolah sold him the rights to her Women's World Championship.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestlingmuseum.com/pages/bios/halloffame/moolahbio.html|title=Hall of Fame Inductee: The Fabulous Moolah|work=The Ring Chronicle|accessdate=May 5, 2009|author=Slagle, Steve|year=2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526141104/http://www.wrestlingmuseum.com/pages/bios/halloffame/moolahbio.html|archivedate=May 26, 2011}} Moolah agreed to appear exclusively for the WWF, and thus became the first [[WWE Women's Championship (1956–2010)|WWF Women's Champion]]. The following year, singer [[Cyndi Lauper]] began a verbal feud with manager [[Lou Albano|"Captain" Lou Albano]], who long had a reputation of being a villain, that brought professional wrestling into mainstream culture in a storyline that became known as the "Rock 'n' Wrestling Connection."{{cite web|url=http://www.salem-news.com/sports/november52007/Moolah_death_110507.php|title=History Making Female Wrestler, The Fabulous Moolah, Dead at 84|publisher=Salem-News.Com Sports|accessdate=July 5, 2008}}Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 169–170. When it was finally time for Lauper and Albano to settle their differences in the ring, a match-up was scheduled with Albano representing Moolah against the challenge of Lauper's protégé, [[Wendi Richter]]. After much buildup and hype, the Fabulous Moolah lost the championship when defeated by Richter, who had Lauper in her corner, on July 23, 1984 in the main event of ''[[The Brawl to End It All]]'', which was broadcast live on [[MTV]].Shields, Brian. ''Main Event: WWE in the Raging 80s'', p. 87. Prior to the match, the WWF promoted Moolah as holding the championship for the previous 28 years. After losing the title to Richter, Moolah aided [[Leilani Kai]] in defeating Richter for the title in February 1985.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/women/304454132121112211 |title=Leilani Kai's reign |publisher=[[WWE]] |accessdate=May 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410132054/http://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/women/304454132121112211 |archivedate=April 10, 2007 |df= }} Richter won it back at the inaugural [[WrestleMania I|WrestleMania]], but when Richter's relationship soured with the WWF, Moolah donned a mask as "The Spider Lady" and regained the belt on November 25, 1985, in a controversial decision. Richter was never told she would be losing the title and fell victim to a real-life "[[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Screwjob|screwjob]]" finish known as "[[Wendi Richter#The Original Screwjob|The Original Screwjob]]".{{cite video|people=Richter, Wendi and Mark Nulty|title=Wendi Richter Shoot Interview|medium=DVD|publisher=HighSpots}} Richter promptly quit the WWF afterward, while Moolah continued to be champion for another two years—excluding a six-day reign by [[Velvet McIntyre]] during a tour of Australia in 1986—before losing the belt to [[Sherri Martel]] on July 24, 1987. She later captained a team at the inaugural [[Survivor Series (1987)|Survivor Series]]. Her team (Moolah, Velvet McIntyre, [[Rockin' Robin (wrestler)|Rockin' Robin]], and the [[Jumping Bomb Angels]]) defeated champion Martel and her team (Leilani Kai, [[Judy Martin (wrestler)|Judy Martin]], [[Donna Christanello]], and [[Dawn Marie Johnston|Dawn Marie]]). ==== Semi-retirement (1987–2007) ==== Throughout the early 1990s, she made appearances in video packages and at live WWF events. On June 24, 1995, she was the first female wrestler to be inducted into the [[WWE Hall of Fame|WWF Hall of Fame]]. In the late 1990s, [[pat Patterson (wrestler)|Pat Patterson]] and Ellison began jokingly discussing a comeback for her, which resulted in Patterson contacting WWF Chairman [[Vince McMahon]] about the possibility.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', p. 205. In 1998, Moolah and [[Mae Young]] re-emerged in the WWF (later renamed World Wrestling Entertainment, WWE). The WWF women's division, however, had since moved away from the traditional athletic match-ups of the past and now featured women competing in sexually-themed [[bikini contest]]s and [[Professional wrestling match types#Strip matches|strip matches]].{{cite web|url=http://www.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingWM2000/apr13_ivory.html|title='Slop' matches haven't stopped Ivory|author=Oliver, Greg|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=August 15, 2008|date=April 13, 2000}} Moolah received a call from McMahon in late 1998 about returning to the company. On the September 9, 1999 episode of ''[[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown!]]'', [[Jeff Jarrett]] invited Moolah, 76, into the ring and smashed a guitar over her head. Moolah and Young then began appearing regularly in comedic roles. On the September 27, 1999 episode of ''[[WWE Raw|Monday Night Raw]]'', Moolah and Young defeated [[Ivory (wrestler)|Ivory]] in a Handicapped Evening Gown match, which led to a title match at [[No Mercy (1999)|No Mercy]] on October 17, 1999. The match saw seventy-six-year-old Moolah defeat Ivory to regain the WWE Women's Championship, thus becoming the oldest WWF Women's Champion ever,Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 2–7. though she lost the title to Ivory eight days later.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/women/30445413212111215 |title=Women's title history: Moolah's reign |publisher=[[WWE]] |accessdate=March 31, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080723230156/http://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/women/30445413212111215 |archivedate=July 23, 2008 |df= }} On the September 15, 2003 episode of ''Raw'', Moolah won a match against [[Lisa Marie Varon|Victoria]].{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2003/09/16/194387.html|title=Raw: Goldberg down but not out|author=Tylwalk, Nick|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=May 5, 2009|date=September 16, 2006}} Moolah had been promised the match for her eightieth birthday and became the first octogenarian to compete in a WWE ring.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/halloffame/fabulousmoolah/bio/|title=Hall of Fame: The Fabulous Moolah|accessdate=December 16, 2007|publisher=[[WWE]]|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071218112356/http://www.wwe.com/superstars/halloffame/fabulousmoolah/bio/ |archivedate = December 18, 2007|deadurl=yes}} After Moolah's victory, the "Legend Killer" [[Randy Orton]] came out and performed an ''[[Cutter (professional wrestling)|RKO]]'' on her. Moolah and Young made another appearance at [[New Year's Revolution (2006)|New Years Revolution]] in 2006, during a [[Professional wrestling match types#Bra & Panties Gauntlet match|Bra and Panties Gauntlet match]] attacking Victoria and stripping her of her top.{{Cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/PPVReports/2006/01/09/1385492.html|title=Edge surprise champ after Revolution|author=Sokol, Chris|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=May 5, 2009|date=January 9, 2006}} She also made brief appearances at [[WrestleMania 23]] and the [[2007 WWE Draft|2007 Draft Lottery]] on June 11, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/PPVReports/2007/04/15/4024168.html|title=Undertaker the champ, McMahon bald|author=Plummer, Dale and Nick Tylwalk|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=May 5, 2009|date=April 1, 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/06112007/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070621160504/http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/06112007/ |archivedate=June 21, 2007 |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |title=One wild night |author=McAvennie, Mike |publisher=[[WWE]] |date=June 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Her last WWE appearance before her death was at [[SummerSlam (2007)|SummerSlam]] in August 2007, in a backstage segment with Vince McMahon and [[list of WWE Raw on-air personalities#authority figures|Raw General Manager]] [[William Regal]]. == Training and promoting == Ellison and her second husband Johnny Long began training women to become female wrestlers, which included [[Ella Waldek]], Daisy Mae, and Katherine Simpson. Long later contacted promoter [[Jack Pfefer]], who agreed to book some of the wrestlers at his shows. After marrying wrestler Buddy Lee, he began helping Ellison train the female wrestlers. After she left Pfeffer's promotion in the 1950s, Ellison found it difficult to book her trainees in shows due to Pfeffer's influence over other [[National Wrestling Alliance]] promoters. Ellison claimed Pfeffer would threaten to reveal the pre-planned nature of wrestling if any other promoters did not do as he liked. As a result, Ellison began selling cosmetics door-to-door and Lee opened a service station to make enough money to pay their bills. They later began to book their wrestlers, including [[Judy Grable]] in Boston, under promoter [[Paul Bowser]]. In the late 1950s when the once-dominant promoter of women's wrestling, [[Billy Wolfe]], was out of business, Ellison and Lee began to book their female wrestlers for more and more shows.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 108–112. They began calling their promoting business Girl Wrestling Enterprises (GWE). Ellison demanded a lot from the girls of GWE, including that they had to keep their hair and make-up done, act like a lady, and not date men who were in the professional wrestling business. In addition to women, Ellison also trained [[Midget wrestling|midget professional wrestler]]s, including [[Katie Glass]] in the 1960s. Ellison founded the Ladies' International Wrestling Association, a non-profit organization to help retired professional wrestlers, in the late 1980s.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', p. 23. In the 1990s, she spent most of her time training female wrestlers at her school in [[Columbia, South Carolina]].Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 8–10. She also began training men, including [[The Patriot (wrestler)|Del Wilkes]], and in 1995 trained more men than women. She also spent time training in Los Angeles at Verne Langdon's Slammers Gym.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', p. 198. ==Allegations of exploitation== ===Financial and sexual exploitation=== Journalist [[Dave Meltzer]] wrote an obituary for Moolah in which he stated that "different promoters had very different ideas of what being professional meant." Wrestling historian Tim Hornbaker said that Moolah "chose not to" break the "dishonest, greedy" practices established by her mentor Billy Wolfe. Pat Laprade and Dan Murphy, in their book ''Sisterhood of the Squared Circle'', wrote that Moolah's "tactics could be just as ruthless and cutthroat as those of 'The Godfather,'" [[Vito Corleone|Don Corleone]]. [[Wendi Richter]] and [[Mad Maxine]] both claimed that Ellison did not actually train the wrestlers at her wrestling school.{{cite web|last1=Fernow|first1=Bill|title=Mad Maxine has quite a story to tell|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2014/08/30/21908686.html|accessdate=14 March 2018}} According to Richter, Ellison accepted payment of the training fee (which at the time of Richter's training was $500) and had other female wrestlers within her camp (including [[Leilani Kai]], [[Judy Martin (wrestler)|Judy Martin]], [[Winona Littleheart]], and [[Joyce Grable]]) train the new recruits; these women did not get paid for their additional work as trainers. Richter also claimed that Ellison required all women that received training at her camp to sign a contract that allowed Ellison to function as their booker and receive 25% of their booking fee. Trainees were also required to rent duplex apartments on Ellison's property and they were responsible for paying her for rent and utilities. The training lasted six months and took place up to five hours per day inside a wrestling ring in a barn that lacked heating and air conditioning or fans. Mad Maxine said that due to owing Moolah both rent and training fees amounting to $1,500, the trainees "went into debt to [Moolah] and she controlled their lives... It was an environment ripe for abuse." Maxine also said that when she went to work for WWF, Moolah was taking at least half of Maxine's earnings. Debbie Johnson, another former trainee of Ellison's, stated that she was required to give Ellison 30% of her booking fee, and her paycheck was further reduced as Ellison deducted travel expenses, food, rent, and utilities before paying her. As a result, Johnson worked for Ellison for two years before she received any money. Johnson stated that Ellison would refuse to book certain women in her training camp if they angered her, and that Ellison monitored her and refused to let her leave the physical constraints of the training camp unless she was accompanied by someone else.{{cite web|url=http://ladysports.com/stories/debbiejohnson.htm|title=LadySports: Shooting with Debbie Johnson |author=Shiai Mata|publisher=LadySports|accessdate=August 25, 2012}} Over the years, various female wrestlers have come forward with stories accusing Ellison of being a [[pimp]] who often provided various wrestling promoters with unsuspecting female wrestlers that would be used as sex objects. [[Penny Banner]] directly described Moolah as a pimp who "in return for money," rented her female trainees out "in bulk" to wrestling promoters so that the promoters and the male wrestlers could have sex with them. Banner said the women who were "sent on these tours were not told of this 'arrangement' ahead of time," and that "those who refused to have sex with wrestlers and promoters were raped." One of the most notorious accusations is from the family of Sweet Georgia Brown (Susie Mae McCoy). McCoy, who was trained and booked by Ellison and her then-husband Buddy Lee, told her daughter that she was often raped, given drugs, and made an addict in an intentional attempt by Ellison and Lee to control her. [[Ida Mae Martinez|Ida Martinez]], who wrestled during the 1960s, also recalls that many of the regional promoters "[[casting couch|demanded personal services]]" before they would pay the female wrestlers.{{cite web|url=http://www.free-times.com/index.php?cat=121304064644348&z_Issue_ID=11012501070771714&ShowArchiveArticle_ID=11012501071127229|archive-url=https://archive.is/20110711025943/http://www.free-times.com/index.php?cat=121304064644348&z_Issue_ID=11012501070771714&ShowArchiveArticle_ID=11012501071127229|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 11, 2011|title=Baby of Sweet Georgia Brown|author=Murfee Faulk|publisher=free-times.com|accessdate=August 14, 2008|date=December 20, 2006}} Mad Maxine described Moolah as an "evil person," saying Moolah made money by sending trainees "out to this guy in Arizona and pimped them out." In a 2002 interview, [[Luna Vachon]] claimed that when she was sixteen years old and training at Ellison's camp, Ellison sent her out of state to be photographed by an older man. Although she remained clothed during the photo shoot, Vachon stated she felt taken advantage of by Ellison and the older man. Vachon also stated that her aunt, [[Vivian Vachon]], witnessed Ellison abusing alcohol and having sex with her female trainees.{{cite web|url=http://thesmartmarks.com/article_1248.shtml|title=Gangrel and Luna Vachon Shoot Interview|publisher=The Smart Marks|accessdate=February 10, 2012}} [[Sandy Parker]], a lesbian former pupil of Ellison's, also claims that Ellison forbade her from going to any gay bars and tried to press her to date men. Parker says this enraged her, because "(Moolah) was two faced because she had her own little dalliances that we all knew about."{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2008/03/14/5009196.html|title=Sandy Parker: Addicted to wrestling|author=Kreiser, Jamie Melissa|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=June 30, 2009|date=April 7, 2008}} However, several former co-workers have spoken out in Ellison's defense. Professional wrestler [[Shane Douglas]] said he never heard anybody speaking against Moolah during his career.{{cite web|url=https://411mania.com/wrestling/shane-douglas-moolah-allegations/|title=Shane Douglas Addresses Allegations Against Fabulous Moolah, Claims He Never Heard Allegations That She Prostituted Female Talents|website=411Mania|first1=Jeffrey|last1=Harris|date=March 31, 2018|access-date=April 19, 2018}} [[Bruce Prichard]] said she was a "wonderful human being" and "She was always good to me, and she treated me well."{{cite web|url=https://411mania.com/wrestling/bruce-prichard-says-undertaker-will-always-welcome-wrestlemania-talks-fabulous-moolah-controversey/|title=Bruce Prichard Says The Undertaker Will Always Be Welcome at WrestleMania, Talks Fabulous Moolah Controversy|website=411Mania|first1=Jeremy|last1=Thomas|date=March 25, 2018|access-date=April 19, 2018}} Former female wrestler Beverly Shade also defended Moolah, claiming "Moolah wasn't that kind of person."{{cite web|url=https://411mania.com/wrestling/former-wrestler-beverly-shade-doesnt-believe-accusations-fabulous-moolah/|title=Former Wrestler Beverly Shade Doesn't Believe Accusations Against Fabulous Moolah|website=411Mania|first1=Larry|last1=Csonka|date=April 19, 2018|access-date=April 19, 2018}} [[Jerry Lawler]] also said he "never heard or saw anything like that when I was in the business around Moolah and her girls."https://411mania.com/wrestling/jerry-lawler-sad-see-moolahs-reputation-defamed-destroyed/ Former trainee Princess Victoria said Moolah never pimp any women or use drugs, but she did take money from them.https://www.solowrestling.com/new/73312-princess-victoria-en-exclusiva-wwe-y-los-mcmahon-han-degradado-a-las-mujeres-durante-mucho-tiempo ===Manipulation of the women's wrestling industry in the United States=== As well as allegedly exploiting female wrestlers sexually, Ellison was accused of using her influence to control the women's wrestling scene and ensure that other women did not gain greater recognition. In addition to being a key participant in [[Wendi Richter#The Original Screwjob|the original screwjob]] on Wendi Richter, Ellison used her influence to take over the spot originally held by her protégé Mad Maxine on the animated series ''[[Hulk Hogan's Rock 'n' Wrestling]]''. Maxine was about to receive a big push by [[Vince McMahon]] but left the WWF shortly afterwards, as Ellison was unwilling to provide her with additional bookings.{{cite web|url=http://www.rspwfaq.com/?p=259 |title=Biggest, Smallest, Strangest, Strongest |author=Scott's Blog of Doom |publisher=rspwfaq.com |accessdate=August 14, 2008 |date=February 10, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120722195434/http://www.rspwfaq.com/?p=259 |archivedate=July 22, 2012 |df= }} Maxine said that Moolah never told her about WWF's plans for Maxine's character to be included on ''Hulk Hogan's Rock 'n' Wrestling''. Numerous other former trainees defected from Ellison after growing tired of sharing their paychecks with Ellison. Women wrestlers including Vivian and Luna Vachon,{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlingdigest.com/2010/10/28/the-phantom-of-the-ring-lipstick-dynamite-and-glowworms-part-31/|title=The Phantom of the Ring: Lipstick, Dynamite and Glowworms, Part 31 – The Vachons|author=Karen Belcher|publisher=Pro Wrestling Digest|accessdate=August 25, 2012}} [[Ann Casey]],{{cite web|url=http://kayfabe-wrestling.com/articles/anncasey01.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019032853/http://kayfabe-wrestling.com/articles/anncasey01.html|archivedate=2007-10-19|title=Ann Casey: More than a Pretty Face |author=Bill Kociaba|publisher=Kayfabe Wrestling|accessdate=August 25, 2012}} and Darling Dagmar{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2010/10/04/pf-15582696.html|title=Darling Dagmar re-enters the wrestling world |author=Greg Oliver|publisher=Slam Wrestling|accessdate=August 25, 2012}} moved into other regions where Ellison had less control and negotiated their own payouts with promoters. Both Judy Martin and Leilani Kai told in later interviews that Moolah would collect the women wrestlers' pay from promoters, and after taking out her own pay, would only give the girls half of the money they were owed (keeping half of their pay for herself, plus her own pay) and telling them that was all the promoter gave her to give them. Martin stated that shortly before Ellison left the WWF in 1988 (shortly after falling out with Martin and Kai due to Ellison no longer receiving their booking fees), she sabotaged the duo while they were touring Japan. Martin stated that Ellison contacted Japanese promoters and informed them that the [[Jumping Bomb Angels]] were supposed to drop the [[WWF Women's Tag Team Championship]] to [[The Glamour Girls]] before Martin and Kai returned to the United States. This was contrary to the booking decision made by [[Pat Patterson (wrestler)|Pat Patterson]] before the Japanese tour began. Unable to reach Patterson by telephone, Kai and Martin agreed to win the titles from the Angels since Ellison had already misinformed the Japanese promoters. Martin stated that upon returning to the United States, Patterson was angry with them and confirmed that nobody within the WWF made the decision for the title change and that due to her long-standing relationship with the company, the WWF refused to listen to their explanation of Ellison's deceit. Shortly thereafter, the WWF phased out the WWF Women's Tag Team Championship. In a later shoot interview, Leilani Kai told that had things gone as the WWF originally planned, The Glamour Girls would have had a title match against the Jumping Bomb Angels at [[WrestleMania IV]] and that Ellison's actions had cost the four girls what would have been ultimately their biggest ever payday.{{cite web|url=http://www.caulifloweralleyclub.org/2012/02/05/2012-cac-womens-honoree-judy-martin/ |title=2012 CAC Women’s Honoree Judy Martin |publisher=Cauliflower Alley Club |accessdate=February 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306170042/http://www.caulifloweralleyclub.org/2012/02/05/2012-cac-womens-honoree-judy-martin |archivedate=March 6, 2016 |df= }} Women that chose to continue allowing Ellison to work as their booker were kept under tight control. [[Velvet McIntyre]] was forced to compete against Ellison (whom McIntyre stated she didn't care for) at [[WrestleMania 2]] instead of competing during an all-women tour of Kuwait with a group of Ellison's other female wrestlers. Their WrestleMania 2 match lasted less than two minutes with the referee ignoring McIntyre's leg being on the ropes while she was being pinned.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2003/03/26/51393.html|title=Velvet's WrestleMania memories |author=Greg Oliver|publisher=Slam Wrestling|accessdate=August 25, 2012}} Women that did not agree to Ellison's booking fees faced limited options. [[Rhonda Sing]] stated that Ellison contacted her and offered to let her wrestle Richter in a couple of pay-per-view matches for the WWF in 1985, but demanded she receive half of Sing's pay check; a stipulation Sing was unwilling to accept.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingBiosS/sing_rhonda_01jan-can.html|title=SLAM! Wrestling Canadian Hall of Fame: Rhonda Sing / Monster Ripper|author=Stephen Laroche|publisher=Slam Wrestling|accessdate=August 14, 2008|date=January 9, 2001}} [[Penny Banner]] stated that her retirement was due in large part to Ellison refusing to allow any of her female wrestlers to accept bookings against Banner, which severely limited the number of bookings that Banner was offered by promoters.{{cite web|url=http://www.glorywrestling.com/News/20040831.asp|title=Joe Rules Interviews G.L.O.R.Y. Legend Penny Banner |author=Joe Rules|publisher=GLORY Wrestling|accessdate=August 25, 2012}} ==Legacy== David Bixenspan of ''[[Deadspin]]'' pointed out that Moolah wrestled an "in-ring style low on athleticism and heavy on hair-pulling", and taught this style to her students. This "worsened the in-genre gender divide" and resulted in American women's wrestling becoming "much more of a sideshow" instead of the women's world title being a "legitimate headline attraction" in the era before Moolah. As such, he rejected WWE's characterization of Moolah as someone who "challenged the gender norms of a once male-dominated sport".{{cite web|last1=Bixenspan|first1=David|title=Fans Are Revolting Against WWE Honoring Fabulous Moolah, With Good Reason|url=https://deadspin.com/fans-are-revolting-against-wwe-honoring-fabulous-moolah-1823744298|work=[[Deadspin]]|publisher=[[Gizmodo Media Group]]|location=United States|date=March 14, 2018|accessdate=March 15, 2018}} [[Dave Meltzer]] described that women's wrestling "went way way down" under Moolah's "tutelage", but he also said he did not know if it was her fault. Meltzer said that although women "used to headline and they were successful", "during the period Moolah controlled women's wrestling, the popularity and product didn't evolve." However, Meltzer noted that Moolah herself "stood the test of time" to remain culturally relevant long after the Japanese female wrestlers of the 1980s (more popular at that time) had faded from relevance.{{cite book|last1=Laparde|first1=Pat|last2=Murphy|first2=Dan|title=Sisterhood of the Squared Circle: The History and Rise of Women’s Wrestling|date=2017|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=1773050141|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=f_lsDQAAQBAJ}} In March 2018, WWE announced "The Fabulous Moolah Memorial Battle Royal", a [[Battle royal (professional wrestling)|battle royal]] for the female wrestlers of the company scheduled for [[WrestleMania 34]] named in honor of Moolah.{{cite web|last1=Powell|first1=Jason|title=WWE Raw Live TV Review: Brock Lesnar and Roman Reigns meet face-to-face, all roads lead to WrestleMania|url=https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/03/12/wwe-raw-live-tv-review-brock-lesnar-roman-reigns-meet-face-face-roads-lead-wrest/|work=Pro Wrestling Dot Net|accessdate=March 12, 2018}} The decision to hold a battle royal in honor of Moolah drew controversy after the allegations of exploitation against Moolah surfaced.{{cite web|title=WWE face fans backlash after they announce the ‘Fabulous Moolah Memorial Battle Royal’|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/other-sports/wrestling/wwe-received-deal-backlash-following-12179980|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|last=Stride|first=Sam|location=[[London]]|date=March 13, 2018|accessdate=March 14, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/5822452/wwe-wrestlemania-fabulous-moolah-memorial-battle-royal/|title=NOT SO FAB: WWE forced into Fabulous Moolah Memorial WrestleMania Battle Royal U-turn after allegations of pimping against legend|first=Gary|last=Stonehouse|work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|location=[[London]]|date=March 16, 2018|accessdate=March 21, 2018}} Two days after the announcement, WWE renamed the match "[[WrestleMania Women's Battle Royal]]", removing Moolah's name from the event.{{cite web|title=WWE changes name of Fabulous Moolah battle royal|url=https://www.f4wonline.com/wwe-news/wwe-changes-name-fabulous-moolah-battle-royal-253621|work=[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]|publisher=Wrestling Observer Newsletter, Inc.|location=United States|last=Currier|first=Joseph|date=March 15, 2018|accessdate=March 15, 2018}} == Other media == An animated version of Moolah was included on a [[CBS]] [[Saturday morning cartoon]] during this lucrative time, titled ''[[Hulk Hogan's Rock 'n' Wrestling]]''.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingReviews/rocknwrestling.html|title=Rock 'n' Wrestling best left in the past|author=Oliver, Greg|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=May 5, 2009|date=December 17, 1999}} In addition, she appeared in one of [[Cyndi Lauper]]'s music videos, "[[The Goonies 'R' Good Enough]]".Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', p. 173. An illness in the mid-1970s meant Ellison had to pull out of the [[Bill Cosby]] movie ''[[Mother, Jugs & Speed]]'', which had a role written specifically for her.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', p. 150. In 2002, Moolah wrote her autobiography, ''The Fabulous Moolah: First Goddess of the Squared Circle''. The book has been criticized for keeping [[kayfabe]] (the stance that wrestling storylines are real) and did not reveal a lot about her time controlling women's wrestling.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2007/11/03/4628394.html|title=Fabulous Moolah dead at 84|author=Oliver, Greg|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=June 18, 2009|date=November 3, 2007}} Defending herself against these claims, Ellison retorted it was hard to fit all of her almost five decade career into one book. Moolah and Young, along with several other female wrestlers, starred in the 2004 film ''[[Lipstick and Dynamite, Piss and Vinegar: The First Ladies of Wrestling|Lipstick and Dynamite]]'' a documentary about the female wrestlers from the 1950s era. They also appeared on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' promoting the film. == Personal life == Ellison's first husband was Walter Carroll, who became the father of her daughter Mary. Mary wrestled briefly but decided against pursuing the profession. Ellison had six grandchildren. Ellison and Carroll divorced shortly after their daughter's birth. Later, Ellison married wrestler Johnny Long.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 55–57. Marital conflicts developed when Long wanted Ellison to be a housewife instead of a career woman. In addition, Ellison accused Long of being a "womanizer". Ellison and Long divorced. Ellison also says that she dated country singer [[Hank Williams]] for four months in 1952. According to Ellison, Williams proposed to her, but Williams's drinking and [[heroin]] abuse forced the couple to go separate ways. She further claimed that he wanted Ellison to quit her wrestling career, which she did not want to do. Two months after the breakup, [[Death of Hank Williams|Williams died]] due to an overdose.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 73–77. Later, Ellison met a wrestler named Buddy Lee, whom she regarded as the "love of her life." They were eventually married, and after divorcing in 1970 after nine years of marriage, they remained friends until Lee's death in 1999.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 82–85. The divorce was attributed to Lee's affair with Rita Cortez, one of the wrestlers the duo was training.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', p. 118. In the early 1980s, Ellison opened Moolah's Hideaway, a bar and grill which was operated by her daughter Mary and frequented by [[André the Giant]].Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 159–160. Beginning in 1991, Ellison lived with [[Mae Young]] in a house in [[Columbia, South Carolina]].{{cite web|url=http://www.austin360.com/movies/content/shared/movies/reviews/L/lipstickanddynamite/ajc.html |title='Lipstick & Dynamite': You'll fall for these ladies |author=Ringel Gillespie, Eleanor |publisher=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |accessdate=July 14, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926105440/http://www.austin360.com/movies/content/shared/movies/reviews/L/lipstickanddynamite/ajc.html |archivedate=September 26, 2008 |df= }} Her estate was located on a road named Moolah Drive. A [[Midget wrestling|midget professional wrestler]] named [[Katie Glass]] also lived with Moolah for over 40 years. Another wrestler, [[Donna Christanello]], also lived with Ellison on-and-off for 40 years, ending in May 1999.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 143–145. During her return to the ring in 1999, Ellison began experiencing occasional dizziness, and as a result, her doctor requested that she begin to wear a heart monitor.Ellison, Lillian. ''First Goddess of the Squared Circle'', pp. 18–22. A few days later, Ellison was admitted to the hospital for what turned out to be two clogged arteries and viral [[pneumonia]]. She stayed at the [[intensive-care unit]] of the hospital for 24 days, during which she was unconscious for fifteen days. After leaving the hospital, she again slipped into unconsciousness in the bathroom at her home, crushing several [[Vertebral column|vertebrae]]. She underwent successful back surgery in mid-December. ===Death=== [[File:Moolah Grave.jpg|thumb|right|Mary Ellison's gravestone in [[Columbia, South Carolina]]]] Ellison died on November 2, 2007 at the age of 84 in Columbia, South Carolina.{{cite news|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/news/fabulousmoolahpasses |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071104183155/http://www.wwe.com/inside/news/fabulousmoolahpasses |archivedate=November 4, 2007 |title=Fabulous Moolah passes away |accessdate=April 22, 2017 |date=November 3, 2007 |publisher=[[WWE]] |deadurl=yes |df= }} According to her daughter Mary, the possible cause of death was a heart attack or blood clot related to a recent shoulder replacement surgery.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/06/sports/06moolah.html?fta=y|title=Mary Lillian Ellison, 84, the Fabulous Moolah, Is Dead|author=Goldstein, Richard|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=March 25, 2009|date=November 6, 2007}} Mary Ellison is buried in a grave plot at Greenlawn Memorial Park in [[Columbia, South Carolina]]. The plot appears to be a family plot designed for The Fabulous Moolah, her daughter Mary, Mae Young, Katie Glass, and add-ons for the rest of her family. == Championships and accomplishments == Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards|Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]''''' ** [[List of Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Worst Worked Match of the Year|Worst Match of the Year]] (1984) {{small|vs. [[Wendi Richter]] on July 23}} * '''Other''' **JWPA Women's Championship{{cite web|url=http://www.fabulousmoolah.com/profile.html|publisher=FabulousMoolah.com|title=Profile|accessdate=May 10, {{infobox Website | name = The Originals | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | url = | company_type = [[Nonprofit]] | location = [[Reet, Belgium]] | type = | registration = 2000 <ref name="ravagedigitaal.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.ravagedigitaal.org/2011/10/artikel.php|title=Waar Abraham de mosterd haalt|publisher=}}</ref> | author = [[Arnold Rypens]] <ref name="originals.be">{{cite web|url=http://www.originals.be/en|title=The Originals © by Arnold Rypens|publisher=}}</ref> | launch date = {{start date|2000}} | commercial = | current status = perpetual work-in-progress }}
'''The Originals''' is a [[database]] [[website]] founded and ran by Arnold Rypens in 2000 <ref name="originals.be"/> and based on a radio show and book series originally launched in 1982.<ref name="originals.be"/> It offers lists of the original versions of thousands of songs and musical compositions and adds every [[cover (music)|cover]] and [[sampling (music)|sample]] made of it since. As of 2017 the site counts more than 15.000 titles.<ref name="originals.be"/>
==Concept==
''The Originals'' was established to track down the original version of every possible [[song]], [[melody]], [[Musical composition|composition]] or [[sampling (music)|sample]]. In many cases the tune listeners would recognize as "the original version" turns out to be much older and far more obscure.<ref name="originals.be"/> Visitors can use a [[search engine]] to type in the name of a musical work or artist and find the corresponding article. Articles about artists or bands provide a list of all of their songs which are covers and/or songs which have been covered. Articles about songs or melodies list all possible musical covers and versions. In both cases the names of each artist, composer, band, songwriter and year of recording are listed. Whenever possible, historical context and background is provided as well. The info is made available both in Dutch as well as English.
==History==
The project is the brainchild of Flemish radio host Arnold Rypens (1952) who established a radio show, ''Domino The Originals'' in February 1982 aired on [[Omroep Brabant]] <ref name="ravagedigitaal.org"/>(nowadays [[Radio 2 (Belgium)|Radio 2]]). It aired nothing but original versions of hits of the day.<ref name="originals.be"/> The emissions sparked interest from listeners who were often surprised and intrigued how old certain songs were and how they sounded in their earliest embryonic versions. As such the show kept running and spawned a special book named ''The Originals - Prequel of the Hits'' (1987)<ref name="standaard.be">{{cite web|url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/dst13122000_064|title=INTERVIEW. Nieuw monnikenwerk van Arnold Rypens|publisher=}}</ref> by Arnold Rypens.<ref name="originals.be"/> This first edition listed some 12.000 music titles,<ref name="originals.be"/> tracing back their earliest versions predating hit version(s) and other relevant covers. Since then up to five new book editions have been published, completely updated and expanded. In 2010 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epo.be/boekenportaal/boekinfo_boek.php?isbn=9789090256832|title=EPO-boekinfo: The Originals - Arnold Rypens|publisher=}}</ref> an English version has been published as well.<ref name="originals.be"/>
Rypens travelled the entire world, researched various libraries, audio collection, museums, archives of [[country music|country]], [[blues]] and [[soul music|soul]] and interviewed collectors and archivists like [[Joel Whitburn]] and [[Alan Lomax]].<ref name="ravagedigitaal.org"/> Rypens' radio show has been broadcast on [[Omroep West-Vlaanderen]], [[Studio Brussel]] and the regional channel Radio L1.<ref name="ravagedigitaal.org"/> To this day Rypens still has a daily segment in the radio program ''Pili Pili'' where he talks about one particular song whose origins he has discovered and mapped out.<ref name="standaard.be"/> The show was also broadcast on [[Radio 3 (Netherlands)|Radio 3]] in the Netherlands by Dutch host [[Hubert van Hoof]]. In 2000 Rypens established a [[website]] around the project.<ref name="ravagedigitaal.org"/>
==Sources== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.originals.be/en Official website] * [http://www.ravagedigitaal.org/2011/10/artikel.php Article about the history of the project] * [http://www.erik.schrijft.nl/gastrijp.htm Interview (in Dutch) with the author] * [https://damusic.be/dossier/arnold-rypens--the-originals-prequel-of-the-hits--de-juiste-vragen-stellen-24237.html A review (in Dutch) ]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Originals, The}} [[Category:Online encyclopedias]] [[Category:Music websites]] [[Category:Online music and lyrics databases]] [[Category:Music search engines]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2000]]

{{Multiple issues| {{no footnotes|date=November 2016}} {{notability|Companies|date=November 2016}} {{advert|date=February 2014}} }}
{{Infobox company | name = ThingLink Oy | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = 2010 | location = [[Helsinki, Finland]] | key_people = Ulla Engeström, <small>CEO</small>, Janne Jalkanen <small>CTO</small> | industry = [[Internet Technology]] | products = Rich Media Tag | num_employees = 14 (2011) | homepage = [http://www.thinglink.com/ www.thinglink.com] }} '''ThingLink Inc.''' (Thinglink Oy in Finland) is a Finnish-American provider of in-image interaction tools.
ThingLink, launched in 2010 and led by [[Ulla Engeström]] and [[Janne Jalkanen]], develops tools for image interaction that allow content sharing via online images. The purpose of ThingLink, according to its developers, is to allow photos and other images to be made into web links, mainly for the purpose of advertising and education.
== Company history ==
ThingLink was developed by Social Objects Oy (a Helsinki-based incubator owned by Ulla and [[Jyri Engeström]]) in 2006. ThingLink was first incorporated in Palo Alto, California in 2008 by Ulla Engeström. A closed test version of the service was launched in 2009, followed by the public release in 2010. Thinglink Oy did initial fundraising and found financial backers in Helsinki. In 2011, ThingLink launched Rich Media Tags, an initial form for linking images to websites and social media. Rich Media Tags have so far been developed for several social content platforms, including [[Facebook]], [[YouTube]], [[Flickr]], [[Spotify]], [[Vimeo]], [[Wikipedia]], [[SoundCloud]] [[Google Apps]] and [[Twitter]].
ThingLink and SoundCloud launched the first use of a sound/music player inside a digital image.{{fix |link=Wikipedia:Citation needed#Citation needed |text=citation needed |class=noprint Template-Fact }}
[[Atlantic Records]] launched [[Simple Plan]]'s [[Get Your Heart On]] CD using ThingLink, the first major record company to tap into the engagement potential of interactive images.
ThingLink hired [[Neil Vineberg]], former head of Vineberg Communications, as CMO, to open up U.S. market to relationships with key companies in music, entertainment, publishing and digital marketing.
== Rich Media Tags == In 2011 ThingLink launched [[Rich Media Tags]], making interacting with different social content platforms possible within a single image.
When linked with a URL to one of the rich media enabled sites, a tag appears revealing the related content. These tags will then be revealed every time a viewer scrolls their mouse over the uploaded image. By using ThingLink, publishers can also include links to other social networks, blogs, news and commerce sites that are yet to have Rich Media Tags created.
